summary: The U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut today entered a final judgment against a defendant who was sentenced to prison for committing a series of high-risk carjackings.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in East Hartford, Connecticut, alleges that, on October 15, 1999, the defendant was released from the Manson Youth Institute, where he had been incarcerated for violating probation after having been convicted on charges of assault in the third degree.  According to the complaint, Johnson told the defendant that he was going to “do something” that night, and that he would meet a friend and family member later to discuss the matter.  Johnson allegedly replied that he did not know why there was a restriction on the imposition of a life sentence for juveniles.  He also allegedly claimed that he had signed a letter of intent without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the defendant provided false testimony to the court, including that he understood Johnson's intent to commit the crime and that the court did not impose a time limitation on the defendant's ability to make a decision about whether to impose a sentence of life imprisonment or the equivalent of a prison sentence on a juvenile.  Instead, the SEC alleges that Johnson violated the antifraud provisions of Section 5 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 5b-5 thereunder, and Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rules 10b-20, 13a-1, and 13b2-3 thereunder. The SEC seeks a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and civil penalties.  On May 24, 2019, the Honorable Judge Robert R. Riley granted the SEC's request for a temporary restraining order, an asset freeze, and an officer-and-director bar against Johnson, and a conduct-based injunction against Johnson from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney.  A hearing on May 25, 2019 was scheduled for 7:30 p.m. The hearing was adjourned until 10:30 a.m., when the defendant and his friend, Rashad Smith, emerged from the bushes behind the car.  Smith and Kelly, who were also present at the hearing, agreed to be permanently enjoined from future securities law violations and to be barred from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities in connection with the issuance of any federal or state securities laws, including the securities laws. The court also granted the defendants' request for an emergency court order requiring the court to consider the mitigating factors of a defendant's prior criminal conviction, including his family and home environment at the time of the alleged carjacking.
